IntroductiontoAnthropology.Description: A survey of what we know about the emergence of humans:  where we came from; how we developed physically and why; how human cultures became more complex through time; and the variety of human ways of life today.

TechnicalAndDigitalSkills: Proficiency in archaeological and anthropological tools
Analyzing data using mapping and GIS software
Documenting findings through digital platforms
Understanding biological and cultural evolution through software analysis
Applying research methodologies in anthropology
InterpersonalAndCommunicationSkills: Writing detailed and well-documented research papers
Discussing complex theories in an interdisciplinary context
ProblemSolvingAndAnalyticalSkills: Reconstructing historical and cultural narratives
Evaluating archaeological and anthropological data critically
Interpreting patterns in human evolution and behavior
Developing innovative approaches to anthropological studies
Synthesizing interdisciplinary research findings
OrganizationalAndLeadershipSkills: Planning and executing fieldwork projects
Managing time effectively during research assignments
Organizing seminars or study groups on anthropology
Leading discussions on anthropological topics
Mentoring peers in applied anthropology practices

BiologicalAnthropology.Description: Human physical and cultural evolution from our earliest primate beginnings through the appearance of anatomically modern humans.

DiggingUpthePast.Description: A comprehensive study of the philosophical and scientific foundations of archaeology and of a general prehistory to which they are applied.  The course includes discussions of methods and theories used to reconstruct ancient Egypt and Mexico and other early cultures.

NorthAmericanArchaeology.Description: The study of the prehistory of native cultures north of Mexico from the peopling of the New World to contact with Europeans.

TopicsinAnthropology.Description: A study of selected topics designed for either majors or nonmajors. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.

TutorialWorkinSpecialTopicsinAnthropolog.Description: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of a member of the graduate faculty. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
